element_texts.text: Completed

Rideout, Walter
2756 Reese Avenue
Evanston, Illinois
August 26, 1957
Dear Jack,
I'll be in Chicago on Thursday the 29th, I think, and will if possible sign the books at Paul Romain's. If I don't make it, I'll let you know so that I can discover the delights of Conroy's Handy Reversible Mailing Wrapper. )Is it plain, and are its contents profusely illustrated always?) I check with Paul Romaine some months ago, and he couldn't find the book; otherwise I would have signed them then. Many thanks for you guidance, Vergil.
From no on I'll be here in Evanston getting ready for the telephone boys.
Up the rebels,
Walter (Rideout)
Completed

Christmas, 1969
Dear Jack and Gladys
Although we love to receive Christmas letters, this is 
the first one we have ever written. Personal notes are 
impossible this year because Jean is working full-time as
assistant Librarian in the University of Wisconsin Library
Scott Library. Quite a change after seventeen years as a 
full-time mother but it's a perfect job for her and good for
everyone, we feel.
Linda and Dick have joined the working force, too so we
are all busy. Linda attends the University of Wisconsin and
chose to live at home. Every Saturday she teaches riding at
Hoofbeat Ridge Ranch, a wonderful two-hundred and fifty acre
farm in beautiful hilly country twenty-five miles west of
Madison. This fits in with yer pre-veterinary course att he
University. Dick is a junior at West High School and finds
time to work twenty-three hours a week at a pet store. He
is making good use of his knowledge of tropical fish. David
is now in his fifth year at St. Coletta School for Exceptional
Children in nearby Jefferson. He is able to write us a note
each week and to read quite well, which is a joy to him and us.
After three years as chairman of the Department of English
and one year's leave at the University's Institute for Research
in the Humanities, Walter is now happily back at full-time
teaching. Last summer he taught in the Harvard Summer School,
and we were lucky to rent the home of friends in Belmont. It
was a busy summer for him but provided us with a wonderful
opportunity to see old friends and revisit favorite places in
the Boston area. A trip to Maine in June included a visit to
the Colby College campus, a Rideout family reunion in Bangor
to celebrate Walter's mother's eightieth birthday, and a
nostalgic tour of the Main coast. We loved seeing New England
again but are all happy to be home in Wisconsin.
With very best wishes for a happy holiday season,
Walter, Jean, Linda, Dick, and David
Dear Jack,
I reviewed David Malden's Proletarian Writers of the Thirties very
favorably in American Literature (November, 1969) and in my seminar
on the 1930's have a very good graduate student, one Denis Gartner,
writing a paper on you. Could you stand being apotheosized in a
doctoral dissertation one of these days?
Faithfully,
Walter
Completed

[Printed on card:] Best wishes in this holiday season
[Handwritten:] Jean and Walter
How is it with the autobiography?  I'm about as interested in reading that as reading the last page of Rideout's biography of Sherwood Anderson, which I'm still working at.  What a fine liar he was.  
Not much news this year.  Jean and I have toiled at our respective tasks.  Our daughter and her husband are now veterinarians and are practicing their healing arts on the cows and horses of Hilton, a small town
Completed

[Printed on card:] The five-colored parakeet  
Emperor hui-tsung, chinese, sung dynasty (1082-1135)  
Maria Antoinette Evans Fund 
Museum of Fine Arts, Boston  
[Handwritten:] 100 miles north of here.  They love the life, but we notice that they come to Madison from time to time to see the bright lights, and they set up at the Rideout Hotel.  Our older son just got his B.S. in Horticulture here at the University.  Our brain-injured younger son is as tall as we and doing well for a handicapped guy.  We're training him to do things on his own, which makes him feel grown-up.  
I've written a couple of articles on Old Sherwood, and last year I wrote 112 recommendation letters.  Why, I could practically have finished my book in that time.  We hope you both had a good 1975 and will have an even better 1976. 
Walter
[Printed on card:] Printed in Switzerland for H. George Caspari, Inc. WXC-1528
Completed

mightily.  The students -- half of them Japanese Americans -- were charming and hard-working, the flowers were gorgeous, the mountains and ocean spectacular, the ethnic and cultural mix of the people fascinating.  The Hawaiians by blood want this land back from Americans and Japanese like the Indians in Maine. 
I still work away at Sherwood Anderson, and teaching, and endless committees. 
Have a great 1978. 
W.
[Printed on card:] From an original by Thor Axelson Drejer 
Exclusive for H. George Caspari, Inc. 
LXA-6804
Printed in Denmark
copyright L. Levinson Junr. Akts. 1976
Completed

Rideout, Walter and Jean 
Madison, Wisconsin 
Dec. 18, 1977 
[Printed on card:] Season's Greetings 
[In a different hand:] Walter and Jean
We hope you are in good shape and the autobiography as well.  The older we get the more concerned we get with our friends' health.  
Last summer I taught in the summer session at the U. of Hawaii in Honolulu and enjoyed myself
Completed
postcard  File:Body of water with hills on each side
Completed

postcard  THE LONG RANGE BETWEN UPPER AND MIDDLE LAKES, KILLARNEY, CO. KERRY:   Moving down from the Upper Lake, regarded by many as the loveliest of the three, through the channel known as Coleman's Eye, the route then enters the Long Range, with the wooded crags of the Eagle's Nest on the left  contributing to an unforgettable scenic experience.
postmark  WINDERMERE CUMBRIA  8 45 PM   26 JNE  1978
Mr. Jack Conroy (Writer)
Fisk Avenue/Street
Moberly, Missouri  U.S.A.
Belsfield Hotel  Bowness on Windermere The Lake Country
June 25, 1978
Dear Jack,
Jean and I have rewarded ourselves for a tough year with a tour of Ireland & the British Isles.   We fell in love with Ireland and the Irish and Edinburgh but found Scotland gorgeous but cold and wet.  Now we've started to move south through England.    This Am. Express tour goes well.  Next time (?)  we'll live in Ireland and England on our own.   Keep well.
Best Walter (Rideout)
Completed

greeting card  File:Snow scene in countryside with children skating and sledding and carrying a Christmas tree

back of the card, continuation of note from inside the card, next page

very friendly and hospitable, and the high school kids come up to you on the street and ask if they can practice some English conversation,  English being required in high school.  The country is an amazing mix of ancient and modern, parking lots beside 1,000 year old temples.  Their gardens are exquisite.  A male chauvinist society, which we did not like, but everyone hardworking as 19th century factory girls.  They are too obedient and status-conscious, but one can walk in the city parks at night unscathed.  We want to go back, stay longer, and learn more.

   Have a underlined:  peaceful and prosperous and healthy 1982.  Let's impeach Reagan et al.   W.
Completed

in pencil in upper margin  [Dec. 1981]
[[greeting card]  Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year
Walter and Jean

    Our big adventure was a trip to Japan last summer.  I taught for two weeks at the Kyoto American Studies Summer Seminar, and then we traveled for a week, to the west, the mountains, Tokyo, Mt. Fuji, assorted shrines.  The people were
Completed

File:Print of hooded figure with sled and four sled dogs   
greeting card    Dog Team . . . by Niviaksiak, one of five sealskin prints "Arctic Life" contributed for the benefit of UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund by the Cape Dorset Eskimos, Baffin Island, Canada.

back of the card, continuation of note from inside the card, next page
the literature of the 1930's that are going to appear soon in universities.  Eventually Dolphin will see the light.  I have real hopes that underlined:  The Disinherited will be  back in print, which is where it ought to be.

    The publishers sent me a copy of Dan Aaron's book.  It looks good.  I've been wildly busy with new courses this fall and haven't even read the daily paper.  (No great loss there.)  It has been a lousy year, but I hope 1962 will be better for us all.

Yours in Christ,
Walter
P.S.  I hope to find time to come in and see you, Jack.  Maybe lunch some day in the Loop?
Completed

in pencil at top of page  Rideout, Walter
greeting card  Happy Holidays from the Rideouts

   Sorry to have missed Bard Conroy's performance last Thursday.   I'll bet it charmed all savage beasts and breasts.
   Two months ago I heard from the Dolphin editor at Doubleday, who wanted to know whether they should publish underlined:  The Disinherited in that series.  (I'm "Consultant in American Literature" for Anchor.  What a title!)  I wrote back strongly urging Dolphin to publish it, but they finally decided not to on the grounds that they could not be sure to sell 10,000 copies right off the bat.  Maybe not that soon could they do it, but I'd argued that the book would be valuable for the courses in 


note continued on preceding photocopied page
Completed

postcard    postmark  RIVERSIDE CA  1A  PM  18 MAY 1970
Gladys & Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, Mo.  65270
Hi -

  Have been spending the month loafing in Calif.  Took off and spent four glorious days in Ensenada.  Have been in Riverside most of the time but also LaCañada (near L.A.) and Pacific Pallisades. [sic]  I regret leaving the Commission but it's a real mess there.   Best wishes Dick Risk
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Risk, Richard E  [1980]
RISK
Sun. 6/21
Dear Jack,

     On Jan. 25, based on your recommendation, Jane and I saw Stephen Wade in Banjo Dancing.  What an absolutely wonderful and delightful time.  The show is still running after 5 months!  What a success!
     We introduced ourselves to Wade as friends of yours and after the show he had us come backstage where he showed us a photo of the two of you of which he was quite proud.  Jane and I
Completed

found him to be quite engaging and are pleased that underlined:  Banjo Dancing is such a success here in Washington.

   Anyhow, we would probably have missed all this if you hadn't written to us about it - thanks so much.  Needless to say our favorite part was your piece.  We may go back and see the show again.
   How are you?  Gladys?  Drop us a brief note sometime.  We think of you often -

As ever, Dick & Jane
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Risk, Richard (Dick)  Alexandria, VA  Dec. 24, 1987
greeting card  and all good wishes for the coming year   Dick and Jane Risk
Jack -

  How are you doing?
  Do you remember this card (note 6₵ postage) sent to us when we had been living in Washington only 2 1/2  months.  As of October it is 16 years and things only get crazier.  But it has been fun for Jane and me and we are bracing ourselves for next year and the presidential election.  Gary Hart is back in the race - says he won't screw up this time.
   Stephen Wade and "Banjo Dancing" are still going strong.  What a success.  Guess I'll go see it again.  Just shows what a person can do if they include your material!

as ever, Dick
Completed

letterhead RICHARD E. RISK     File:Line in the shape of a head changing into an arrow pointing at the name
in pencil below name   [no date]
Friday
Jack -

    Here is the"item" Jane and I promised to mail you.  We got a laugh out of it - hope you do too.
    We sure had a great time seeing you and Gladys - always enjoy our visits!

Dick
Completed

Chesterton, Ind
R.R. #2. Box 434.
May 4, '50
Dear Jack:

  Thanks for remembering me with an announcement of Anita Lipp's concert.  Indeed, I am always happy to have an opportunity to contribute my few pence to any thing of a cultural aspect.   For my ears ring with savage war crap, and my reluctant purse is shrunken thereby.
  Anyway, I'm sorry we missed the concert.  We're here on the "poor man's acres" for the summer.  We're raising Capons.  A nasty business, this.  With my scalpel I remove the gland that makes a cockrel a cock.  But thereafter they do [sic] have to exert themselves crowing at early dawn, nor chasing the virgin pullets over the acres.  All of which adds fat to their rumps. 
   We want you folks out for a week-end.  You'll enjoy it.  A sniff of the Hoosier Country side 'll do you good.

As ever.  Bill Robinson
Completed

letterhead  Charles H. Kerr Publishing Company  Established 1886  1740 Greenleaf Avenue, Suite 7  Chicago, Illinois  60626
12 OCT 85
Dear Jack Conroy -

   I have been a fan of your writing for a good while now and have just moved from Chicago to Columbia to teach at University of Missouri.  It was great to see the article about you in the underlined: Tribune (or was it the underlined:  Missourian ?)  last week.
   I am writing to ask you to join in endorsing the 100th anniversary fund appeal of the Charlie H. Kerr Company, America's oldest labor and socialist publisher.  Some items on Kerr's recent revival and a list of people sponsoring the "Friends of Kerr" are enclosed.  We are not asking for contributions but for the lending of your name and prestige to the appeal.

Sincerely,
Dave Roediger
Completed

postcard  ROEDIGER  UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI-COLUMBIA  143 ARts and Science Columbia Missouri 6 [end of lines covered by bar-code sticker]]  Department of History

JACK CONROY
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO  
65270
Completed

3 Sept.87
Dear Jack Conroy -

   When you came down last April for the Mo. Conference on History you mentioned having known the radical labor journalist, Harvey O'Connor.   Harvey died last week, at 90.  If you would get a chance to write a condolence to his widow, I'm certain she'd appreciate it.  The address is Jessie Lloyd O'Connor/ Warren Point Road / Little Compton, RI  02837.
   Hope all is well in Moberly.

Solidarity.
Dave Roediger
Completed

No word from your underlined:  100 magazine.
Jack I:

    Up to nothing - finishing art on GI Bill - tried without luck to tie up with some Adv. Agency in Wash. last summer - guess my age agin me in spite of obvious talent.  Smithsoman [sic] show had good write-ups - I got more publicity than any other local artist in recent years - sales about paid for expense of matting - a Chicagoan, Alfred London, 5063 Wash. Blvd., bought a soldier drawing from show - one of my best pictures, dad gum it - I never met the guy just got his check - tell him hello if you run into him, or hear of him.  Didnt know Aswell underlined: had  a novel, must be another author of same name - Aswell now writes propaganda for guvmint gang - them as has all the mink coats, etc.  The underlined:  STAR  gave you a good plug - only decent paper in D.C. and that doesn't say much.

Hastily, Jack II
in pencil in left margin  No see Judy's book - got no money for books, only beer.
Completed

in red pencil at top of page  underlined: Return from John C. Rogers
first two sentences have red lines drawn along both sides and under the second sentence
Thursday - 15th
Dear Comrade:

  No. 16 of R. Poet has been forwarded to me.  I like the cover arrangement better than previous issues.  The idea of producing Unrest 1932 to sell for $1.00 & .50 is excellent - it will not affect the contents and should make a wider distribution possible.  I am not in a position to give either financial of [sic] physical aid at present - perhaps in a month or two.
   I am in the foothills of the Blue Ridge, in the Rockfish Valley, among share-croppers and tenant farmers.  I have not been so poor in my life, and altho I am here mainly for my health - I would like to help in some way the R. Poet.  In a month or so I hope to be back in the city where
Completed

I can at least do some linoleum cuts, and run down a subscription or two.  I have not  been well - due perhaps to my injury received when a tree surgeon for the Hoover regime, and possibly due to a slight sunstroke -  at times I have contemplated taking Harry Crosby's solution, but the fact the newspapers would chortle over another radical's suicide has kept me alive - Why, I do not know - I am too much a part of the working-class to give up my beliefs in order to accept a job by licking somebody's boots - but I can't go on like this - Either I manage to sell some drawings or a piece of prose, or I cash out - I lack the health & strength to grab a  freight and do organization work among
Completed

hill-billies and unemployed - and I am too sensitive to the suffering of others to remain in my bourgeoise home-town and keep my mouth shut - I can't leave the Left road, and I certainly have no desire to leave it, but being jack-of-several-trades, and master of none, I am in a good position to be ruined by the sweep of the capitalist crisis.

  I have had an enjoyable time at the University of Virginia talking to students and instructors concerning America's destiny - and I know that such organs as the R. Poet, Liberator, New Masses, etc. are greatly needed to combat the flood of Fascist propaganda let loose in the colleges and press.  WE must become pamphleteers if we are to build the foundations of a Soviet America.

Fraternally, Jack
Completed

How much do you get for a best seller?  Friend of mine says not too much if the book comes out at the wrong time and the guvmint takes its cut.  Lo the poor Indian!  Lo the po' whites in Appalachia!  Lo the po' folks in the Ozarks!  Read Judy's review of G. Code's book - awful review and nothing about THE BOOK.  Cheers.  JCR/
in right margin  Receive underlined:  The News?

Jack Conroy, Esq.
701 Fisk Avenue
MOBERLY, Missouri  65270
Portugese [sic] town with railroad to the top.  Cathedral of course.  No, I didn't see the FOOLKILLER, nor hear nothing from Curt et cetera.  Living is such happy bliss.  Didn't have no poke sallit neither.  Jack II.
Completed

Jack III/
Dee & Sally Brown at underlined in re:  Univ. of Illinois - look them up - sent your letter on to them - he is working for degree and also teaching Library Science class, I believe - address:
Dee Brown
Court Eye - 60-D
Stadium Terrace
Champaign, Illinois - until next 8 or 9 months.

     Thanks for passing stories on - the editors seem impressed with one.  I also told Murrell Edmunds about mag - he will submit, as a novel coming out next month.
     Lost Quaker gals in shuffle - wish I knew - called their apt once but they had gone without no forwarding address - guess they are in Philly - always losing wimmen - no more sex appeal I guess.
     Speak a kind word to Jack Sherby's ex-wife - underlined:  Ollie Sherby, 18247 Argyle Avenue, Homewood, Illinois - last working for Mine, Mill & Smelters' union - she is lonesome - send some emissary around.  also contact Howard Swenson, 1822 Charles St., Rockford, Ill.  -

Hastily, Jack II
in left margin  Aswell & I think Ben-the Bot is a WPA folklore racketeer - you're real he's phony and false to his friends.
Completed

Jack II

   What's the drift about underlined: The Trumpet?  Folded up and tooken my story with them, or awaiting publication and new address?  Can't let us writing folks down like that, bad for the great American novel.
    I have a batch of my published stuff typed up on account Coleman Rosenbeger thought I should do so and submit to a publisher.  Can you give me a steer - where should I send it -to an agent like Lieber (his address?) or to a publisher?  I also thought of applying for a Saxton (Harper) Fellowship, since they claim to help unpublished and unknown authors.  What do you think?  I have about eight (8) mss. typed - from underlined:  The Anvil, Virginia Spectator,  Wash. D.C. underlined: Post and underlined: Hinterland.
  What ever became of Ellington (The Critic) Custis?  Last time I saw him was in hills of Va. when we got berled on cawn juice.  Is he daid?
  Drop me brief and quick line or two - You know Rayford's address?

Jack III
Completed

in pencil in top margin   6012 So. Green St. Chicago 21.
Jack I

     Ever see Dee Brown or his new book?  Thought you might want enclosed for your collection.  haven't seen the exhibit - don't get to Library since I work part-time nights in D.C. Library.
    Look up my friend and excellent composer, underlined: Al SCHOONMAKER, 3420 North Paulina, Chicago 13.  -says he lives under elevated and exists on fish, beer & pumpernickle - I heard a recording of one of his quartets and liked it very much.  Think he works in a machine shop, or used to - he's from Milwaukee & was in Europe with an army buddy of mine.  Al is getting restless - going to New York in Sept. - you may know someone who can help him in Chicago music field?  Anyway, have a brew with him and write - even a card.

Best.  Jack II.
in right margin  Have an art show at Univ of Virginia now thru April 14.
in pencil in left margin  Never heard from Chicago mag - is it still published?
Completed

"Potherly" does not believe all he writes - he writes that way to get published -!?
Jack I -

    What's new, if anything?  Enclose two letters - under pseudonym of course - thought you might want to forward "hillbilly" one to  B.A. ?Botlein?.
     How do you go about getting job of illustrating childrens' books - or such?  Do you know an agent who handles art work?
     Heard from Julian Lee Rayford - he's doing autobiographical novel of his WPA days.
    Let us hear from you sometime.

Jack II
115 E. Maple
Alex Va.
